author: jpeg68
title: Part of a starter set.
review:
I have this as part of a boxed starter set (a similar idea to the German 880002 but in one, big simple box). It is not sponsored, like some, by Shell but Merlin, a UK sticker trading company. It contains the bases, a 3303, 3306, five England players and five World players, plus some Merlin stickers. 
 What is interesting is that the set has no number apart from a red "1" in the top right corner. In fact, none of the sets inside have numbers (aside from the red ones) either. Thus it would be almost impossible to categorise the set unless you gave it an arbitrary number or called it simply, "1"? 
 I will submit a photo of it to Brickset and see how they cope with it. 
 A fun set, nevertheless, especially with all the other accessories added. In a final note, mine came with Scotland stickers but England players!

author: toofpikk
title: ok.
review:
this set ids really only ideal if you have lots and lots and lots of bricks or some lego football sets. me and my big brother got it as a christmas present from my dad, we built it (it had 2 stands, a commentary box with some police cars). we opened this first for we were really excited with long thin presents, then in the afternoon we didnt want it to be a football stadium anymore

it doesnt come with any figures or any spare peices, just 2 plane football boards.

if you are going to get this for a present to someone, unless they have lots of lego dont buy it, if they do, then watch the prices  for if it goes over £5 its not worth it but never go over £10

 

thanks for reading

author: Mawich
title: The start of something big
review:
This set represents my first foray into purchasing Lego via the internet back in 1998.  I can still vividly remember the day reading a post on the Lego newsgroup website early that year announcing the arrival of this and related sets. 

I had been collecting Classic Town for years up to that point but never in my wildest dreams imagined TLG would ever release a sports stadium.  This "starter set" came with instructions for 3 games, a precursor to the enlarged Football range that would follow a couple of years later.  

The picture suggests a stadium with only three sides but I was able to create a completely enclosed stadium by purchasing and modifying 16 of the headstand sets (3309). The finished stadium looks awesome and is a great addition to a larger town layout.  Pictures of the stadium I built are at http://www.brickshelf.com/cgi-bin/gallery.cgi?m=mawich

author: Flash88
title: The start of my LEGO football experience
review:
This set was the platform for many years of absolute enjoyment of LEGO Football from 1998 onwards for me.

Yes it's a basic set - literally just the pitch, but for me the box was something that attracted me as a kid. I actually wanted my stadium to look like the one on the box, and would save up all my pocket money to try and get enough to buy the grandstands to go around it.

While future sets made things quite restrictive, the basic-ness (for want of a better word!) of this set led to hours of imaginative fun.

I can still hear the sound of the ball running along the green bumps.

If you want something to build, this isn't it. But as a base for a collection and for something to aspire to (e.g. what's on the box) then great.
